The description is clear but could benefit from some refinements. Emphasize that the architect must balance creating a challenging maze with ensuring at least one hero escapes to pass the test. Clarify the roles of each entity (monsters, obstacles, treasures) and explain how hero scores are calculated. Provide an example of valid entity placements to show the output format. Add comments in the C++ code for better understanding, especially for beginners. Finally, give tips on optimizing maze design within the 25-second time constraint and suggest strategies for hindering heroes effectively.

Seems pretty good to me, but I would share a lot of the same criticisms as Bulgot - The maze really should be visible from the first turn
Good

I love the concept, but it current state it would be hardly playable. Two reasons:

1. Rule of '1 guy must survive' is opposite of fun. Imagine 100m run, fastest wins, but faster than 20s autoloses. Completely different sport, that punishes you for being faster. It's same here, making a bit better maze can result in killing last guy, which is autolose.   I think it would be a lot better to get rid of that rule, but of course then you would need other rules like 'there must be walking path to exit', 'no building monsters too close to hero' etc.

2. Scoring. Current 10000 for passing, -1000 for death worked great for "Code Keeper - The Hero". But not here, especially with above problem. Currently, 1 more guy passing in one case totally negates points from all gold/monsters you prevented in other cases. Same with death, the difference is far to high. I would try 100 for passing, 0 for death
(beacause death/stay in place  is hard to differ from architect perspective) 

How I can see this, currently it will all be about how to let 1 guy through and kill 3, on every case. Which is about finding behaviour difference between bots. And how to not let any bot stuck (as they won't die then). So its about adjusting to bots AI instead of building dungeon.

And 3rd smaller thing - please make maze visible from first turn. Not being albo to see maze when debugging errors is annoying. And its hard to start, I can't see maze beacause I don't know where to place entities, because I can't see the maze.

@Bulgot is exactly right that these rules make the game NOT about finding the "best" maze. But I guess I disagree that it is inherently bad for the solution to depend on understanding/predicting the heroes strategies... as long as the strategies of the heroes are meaningfully chosen and provided.

It isn't really "a race where being too fast disqualifies you"; it's more a competition to predict the outcome of that race, right? The goal isn't to construct the "hardest" maze, rather the goal is to construct a maze with a predictably bad outcome.

If your maze kills all of the heroes, then you weren't really predicting their behavior, and that deserves a bad score. 

That said, it would be BETTER if finding the optimal solution didn't DEPEND on fully simulating the heroes, and there was some property of at least one strategy that could be exploited to quickly "check" that a maze is solvable (by that strategy).

I think which 4 strategies are chosen is what determines whether this game is good or bad.

EDIT: Could it be proven that at least one of the heroes strategies can solve any theoretically solvable maze? If not for the current set of heroes strategies, then for some set of 4 strategies? (Note that the strategies can be more complex if the solution doesn't depend on simulating the heroes. and the coder can reliably assume that a solvable maze can/will be solved.)
